overview.short: Providencia stuartii is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic Enterobacterales species strongly associated with healthcare-associated urinary tract infections.
overview.clinical_context: Classically linked to catheter-associated UTIs, long-term care facilities, and opportunistic infections in debilitated patients.

species_markers.notes: Strong contextual signal: frequent in chronic catheterisation and nursing-home settings.
More reliably urease-positive than P. alcalifaciens and often stronger than P. rettgeri.
Supports separation from P. alcalifaciens (typically indole-negative).

common_confusions.reason: Both can be indole-positive with overlapping biochemical traits; differentiation may require a full panel.
Shared urease positivity and Enterobacterales profile; Proteus shows swarming.

when_to_question_identification: Swarming growth argues for Proteus rather than Providencia.
Citrate positivity suggests Enterobacter/Citrobacter rather than Providencia.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Supports P. stuartii when clearly positive, and helps separate from some close Enterobacterales lookalikes.
Best practical biochemical panel for Enterobacterales differentiation in routine labs.
